HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 4, 1924

DO YOU REMEMBER?
Do you remember the thrill of victory over St. John's in 1921,.
which decided the State Championship? And, do you remember the
score in 1922 of Hopkins 16, St. John's 7, and in 1923 Hopkins 3, St.
John's 0? These three victories, all within the experience of the
present Senior Class, are sufficient examples to demonstrate the athletic superiority of Johns Hopkins over St. John's. There is little
doubt that this year Captain Magill will engage in a victorious game
over St. John's for the fourth time during his college career.
But, do you remember that always in the past St. John's has
been primed for the Hopkins contest? Do you remember that, no
matter what comparative scores have indicated, the contest has al..
waysbeen close? This year, when Hopkins and St. John's meet for
the thirty-seventh time, will be no exception. And, do you remember how rooting and celebration have been helpful to the team in
the past? Yet, good sportsmanship has always characterized the
game. Do you remember the traditional bonfires and parades which
have lent distinction to a Hopkins-St. John's game? And the snake
dance after victory? A Hopkins-St. John's clash without symptoms
of the "St. John's fever" would be remarkable.
Let's make a bonfire that will illustrate to some extent the
warmth of the reception St. John's will receive at the Stadium on
Saturday. But, let us remember at all times that parades, bonfires,
or any celebrations are Hopkins activities, the participants Hopkins
men, and that Hopkins will be judged by our actions on these occasions.

We haven't had any pep meetings or yell practice for some time.
Before the St. John's game is a good time to arouse a little pep.

BETTING
The Student Council and the Athletic Association have requested again that the students refrain from offering or accepting bets on
athletic contests in which Hopkins team participate. At first glance
betting on games as evidence of confidence in a team's ability is an
innocent form of amusement. It is easily apparent, however, that
organized collegiate betting will tend to commercialize collegiate and
amateur games. Collegiate athletics are too popular, too sacred an
institution to be thus imperiled.

This Year

Probably few men realize what
a great change has been made in
Hopkins traditions by the removal of the University to Homewood
from the old site on Druid Hill
avenue. Gone is our old alley
campus, the narrow block of Garden street between Druid Hill
avenue and Monument street.
Here the "Charles Street Cowboys." of bygone days lounged on
packing boxes in the short strip of
sunlight that fell between the
walls of McCoy Hall and the late
lamented cage. From nine in the
morning until two-thirty in the
afternoon the ancient and honorable sport of pitching dimes was
the only pastime. Shortly after
lunch the scene of activity shifted
to the first floor of Levering Hall,
the Student Y. M. C. A. Building,
located on the corner of Eutaw
street and Druid Hill avenue. Arrayed in chairs, with feet lined
along the window sill the Hopkins men watched the girls. of
Western High School pass in review.
Alumni of the day of Governor
Ritchie will remember the "Pot
Socials" held in the old locker
room on the ground floor of the
gym. This small room, formerly
a kitchen, was the gathering place
of Sophomores. At almost any
time of day a •FreshMan might be
seen making a hasty and inglorious exit to the accompaniment of

hoots and jeers from the "pep
committee" whose session he had
in
Places in the McCoy Hall elevator were strictly in order ol
seniority. Freshmen were not allowed upon it at all and few Sophomores and Juniors were able
to resist ejectment if they were
fortunate enough to get on board
during the ten-minute intervals
between periods.
Two years ago saw the passing
of one tradition. The Student
Council called off the usual fight
between the Freshman and Sophomore classes after the Y. M.
C. A. reception which in the old
days was held around the fountains in Mt. Vernon Place and in
recent years around the pond in
front of the Barn..
Nor does the Senior class on the
last day parade through the buildings to the accompaniment of its
Swan Song, "We Won't Be Here
Any More."
This year Freshmen no longer
retire to the secrecy of the tunnels for their noon-day "smokes."
Instead they appear walking upon
the campus, in fact on the grass,
their hands in their pockets, and
smoking the forbidden weed.
Doc Adams followed us to
Homewood, but Fritz's Cafe has
no connotations to the present
generation of Hopkins men. Sic
transit gloria mundi.

DO YOU REMEMBER?
Do you remember the thrill of victory over St. John's in 1921,.
which decided the State Championship? And, do you remember the
score in 1922 of Hopkins 16, St. John's 7, and in 1923 Hopkins 3, St.
John's 0? These three victories, all within the experience of the
present Senior Class, are sufficient examples to demonstrate the athletic superiority of Johns Hopkins over St. John's. There is little
doubt that this year Captain Magill will engage in a victorious game
over St. John's for the fourth time during his college career.
But, do you remember that always in the past St. John's has
been primed for the Hopkins contest? Do you remember that, no
matter what comparative scores have indicated, the contest has al..
waysbeen close? This year, when Hopkins and St. John's meet for
the thirty-seventh time, will be no exception. And, do you remember how rooting and celebration have been helpful to the team in
the past? Yet, good sportsmanship has always characterized the
game. Do you remember the traditional bonfires and parades which
have lent distinction to a Hopkins-St. John's game? And the snake
dance after victory? A Hopkins-St. John's clash without symptoms
of the "St. John's fever" would be remarkable.
Let's make a bonfire that will illustrate to some extent the
warmth of the reception St. John's will receive at the Stadium on
Saturday. But, let us remember at all times that parades, bonfires,
or any celebrations are Hopkins activities, the participants Hopkins
men, and that Hopkins will be judged by our actions on these occasions.

We haven't had any pep meetings or yell practice for some time.
Before the St. John's game is a good time to arouse a little pep.

BETTING
The Student Council and the Athletic Association have requested again that the students refrain from offering or accepting bets on
athletic contests in which Hopkins team participate. At first glance
betting on games as evidence of confidence in a team's ability is an
innocent form of amusement. It is easily apparent, however, that
organized collegiate betting will tend to commercialize collegiate and
amateur games. Collegiate athletics are too popular, too sacred an
institution to be thus imperiled.

WHEN UNIVERSITY MOVED TO HOME WOOD
Alley Campus, McCoy Hall, Cage, Fritz Cafe, and the Traditional Haunts
Left; When Hopkins Was Transplanted; Other Traditions Lost
This Year

Probably few men realize what
a great change has been made in
Hopkins traditions by the removal of the University to Homewood
from the old site on Druid Hill
avenue. Gone is our old alley
campus, the narrow block of Garden street between Druid Hill
avenue and Monument street.
Here the "Charles Street Cowboys." of bygone days lounged on
packing boxes in the short strip of
sunlight that fell between the
walls of McCoy Hall and the late
lamented cage. From nine in the
morning until two-thirty in the
afternoon the ancient and honorable sport of pitching dimes was
the only pastime. Shortly after
lunch the scene of activity shifted
to the first floor of Levering Hall,
the Student Y. M. C. A. Building,
located on the corner of Eutaw
street and Druid Hill avenue. Arrayed in chairs, with feet lined
along the window sill the Hopkins men watched the girls. of
Western High School pass in review.
Alumni of the day of Governor
Ritchie will remember the "Pot
Socials" held in the old locker
room on the ground floor of the
gym. This small room, formerly
a kitchen, was the gathering place
of Sophomores. At almost any
time of day a •FreshMan might be
seen making a hasty and inglorious exit to the accompaniment of

hoots and jeers from the "pep
committee" whose session he had
in
Places in the McCoy Hall elevator were strictly in order ol
seniority. Freshmen were not allowed upon it at all and few Sophomores and Juniors were able
to resist ejectment if they were
fortunate enough to get on board
during the ten-minute intervals
between periods.
Two years ago saw the passing
of one tradition. The Student
Council called off the usual fight
between the Freshman and Sophomore classes after the Y. M.
C. A. reception which in the old
days was held around the fountains in Mt. Vernon Place and in
recent years around the pond in
front of the Barn..
Nor does the Senior class on the
last day parade through the buildings to the accompaniment of its
Swan Song, "We Won't Be Here
Any More."
This year Freshmen no longer
retire to the secrecy of the tunnels for their noon-day "smokes."
Instead they appear walking upon
the campus, in fact on the grass,
their hands in their pockets, and
smoking the forbidden weed.
Doc Adams followed us to
Homewood, but Fritz's Cafe has
no connotations to the present
generation of Hopkins men. Sic
transit gloria mundi.
